author: Grimms
text: A long time ago there lived a king who was famed for his wisdom through all the land.

author: Grimms
text: Nothing was hidden from him, and it seemed as if news of the most secret things was brought to him through the air.

author: Grimms
text: But he had a strange custom; every day after dinner, when the table was cleared, and no one else was present, a trusty servant had to bring him one more dish.

author: Grimms
text: It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.

author: Grimms
text: This had gone on for a long time, when one day the servant, who took away the dish, was overcome with such curiosity that he could not help carrying the dish into his room.

author: Grimms
text: When he had carefully locked the door, he lifted up the cover, and saw a white snake lying on the dish.

author: Grimms
text: But when he saw it he could not deny himself the pleasure of tasting it, so he cut of a little bit and put it into his mouth.

author: Grimms
text: No sooner had it touched his tongue than he heard a strange whispering of little voices outside his window.

author: Grimms
text: He went and listened, and then noticed that it was the sparrows who were chattering together, and telling one another of all kinds of things which they had seen in the fields and woods.

author: Grimms
text: Eating the snake had given him power of understanding the language of animals.

author: Grimms
text: Now it so happened that on this very day the queen lost her most beautiful ring, and suspicion of having stolen it fell upon this trusty servant, who was allowed to go everywhere.

author: Grimms
text: The king ordered the man to be brought before him, and threatened with angry words that unless he could before the morrow point out the thief, he himself should be looked upon as guilty and executed.

author: Grimms
text: In vain he declared his innocence; he was dismissed with no better answer.

author: Grimms
text: In his trouble and fear he went down into the courtyard and took thought how to help himself out of his trouble.

author: Grimms
text: Now some ducks were sitting together quietly by a brook and taking their rest; and, whilst they were making their feathers smooth with their bills, they were having a confidential conversation together.

author: Grimms
text: The servant stood by and listened.

author: Grimms
text: They were telling one another of all the places where they had been waddling about all the morning, and what good food they had found; and one said in a pitiful tone: "Something lies heavy on my stomach; as I was eating in haste I swallowed a ring which lay under the queen"s window."

author: Grimms
text: The servant at once seized her by the neck, carried her to the kitchen, and said to the cook: "Here is a fine duck; pray, kill her."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said the cook, and weighed her in his hand; "she has spared no trouble to fatten herself, and has been waiting to be roasted long enough."

author: Grimms
text: So he cut off her head, and as she was being dressed for the spit, the queen"s ring was found inside her.

author: Grimms
text: The servant could now easily prove his innocence; and the king, to make amends for the wrong, allowed him to ask a favour, and promised him the best place in the court that he could wish for.

author: Grimms
text: The servant refused everything, and only asked for a horse and some money for travelling, as he had a mind to see the world and go about a little.

author: Grimms
text: When his request was granted he set out on his way, and one day came to a pond, where he saw three fishes caught in the reeds and gasping for water.

author: Grimms
text: Now, though it is said that fishes are dumb, he heard them lamenting that they must perish so miserably, and, as he had a kind heart, he got off his horse and put the three prisoners back into the water.

author: Grimms
text: They leapt with delight, put out their heads, and cried to him: "We will remember you and repay you for saving us!"

author: Grimms
text: He rode on, and after a while it seemed to him that he heard a voice in the sand at his feet.

author: Grimms
text: He listened, and heard an ant-king complain: "Why cannot folks, with their clumsy beasts, keep off our bodies?

author: Grimms
text: That stupid horse, with his heavy hoofs, has been treading down my people without mercy!"

author: Grimms
text: So he turned on to a side path and the ant-king cried out to him: "We will remember you--one good turn deserves another!"

author: Grimms
text: The path led him into a wood, and there he saw two old ravens standing by their nest, and throwing out their young ones.

author: Grimms
text: "Out with you, you idle, good-for-nothing creatures!" cried they; "we cannot find food for you any longer; you are big enough, and can provide for yourselves."

author: Grimms
text: But the poor young ravens lay upon the ground, flapping their wings, and crying: "Oh, what helpless chicks we are!

author: Grimms
text: We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot fly!

author: Grimms
text: What can we do, but lie here and starve?"

author: Grimms
text: So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food.

author: Grimms
text: Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: "We will remember you--one good turn deserves another!"

author: Grimms
text: And now he had to use his own legs, and when he had walked a long way, he came to a large city.

author: Grimms
text: There was a great noise and crowd in the streets, and a man rode up on horseback, crying aloud: "The king"s daughter wants a husband; but whoever seeks her hand must perform a hard task, and if he does not succeed he will forfeit his life."

author: Grimms
text: Many had already made the attempt, but in vain; nevertheless when the youth saw the king"s daughter he was so overcome by her great beauty that he forgot all danger, went before the king, and declared himself a suitor.

author: Grimms
text: So he was led out to the sea, and a gold ring was thrown into it, before his eyes; then the king ordered him to fetch this ring up from the bottom of the sea, and added: "If you come up again without it you will be thrown in again and again until you perish amid the waves."

author: Grimms
text: All the people grieved for the handsome youth; then they went away, leaving him alone by the sea.

author: Grimms
text: He stood on the shore and considered what he should do, when suddenly he saw three fishes come swimming towards him, and they were the very fishes whose lives he had saved.

author: Grimms
text: The one in the middle held a mussel in its mouth, which it laid on the shore at the youth"s feet, and when he had taken it up and opened it, there lay the gold ring in the shell.

author: Grimms
text: Full of joy he took it to the king and expected that he would grant him the promised reward.

author: Grimms
text: But when the proud princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task.

author: Grimms
text: She went down into the garden and strewed with her own hands ten sacksful of millet-seed on the grass; then she said: "Tomorrow morning before sunrise these must be picked up, and not a single grain be wanting."

author: Grimms
text: The youth sat down in the garden and considered how it might be possible to perform this task, but he could think of nothing, and there he sat sorrowfully awaiting the break of day, when he should be led to death.

author: Grimms
text: But as soon as the first rays of the sun shone into the garden he saw all the ten sacks standing side by side, quite full, and not a single grain was missing.

author: Grimms
text: The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.

author: Grimms
text: Presently the king"s daughter herself came down into the garden, and was amazed to see that the young man had done the task she had given him.

author: Grimms
text: But she could not yet conquer her proud heart, and said: "Although he has performed both the tasks, he shall not be my husband until he had brought me an apple from the Tree of Life."

author: Grimms
text: The youth did not know where the Tree of Life stood, but he set out, and would have gone on for ever, as long as his legs would carry him, though he had no hope of finding it.

author: Grimms
text: After he had wandered through three kingdoms, he came one evening to a wood, and lay down under a tree to sleep.

author: Grimms
text: But he heard a rustling in the branches, and a golden apple fell into his hand.

author: Grimms
text: At the same time three ravens flew down to him, perched themselves upon his knee, and said: "We are the three young ravens whom you saved from starving; when we had grown big, and heard that you were seeking the Golden Apple, we flew over the sea to the end of the world, where the Tree of Life stands, and have brought you the apple."

author: Grimms
text: The youth, full of joy, set out homewards, and took the Golden Apple to the king"s beautiful daughter, who had now no more excuses left to make.

author: Grimms
text: They cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it together; and then her heart became full of love for him, and they lived in undisturbed happiness to a great age.
